title: Convicted pedophile Gary Glitter will not receive royalties for song featured in 'Joker'
text:
CLOSE

British glam rocker Gary Glitter, a convicted pedophile, will not receive any money from his song featured in the new "Joker" film.

The film ignited an uproar for a crucial scene that features a transformed and fully face-painted Arthur Fleck (Joaquin Phoenix) dancing down stairs to the tune of Glitter's "Rock and Roll (Part 2)," a 1970s hit on both sides of the ocean.

Snapper Music, the UK record label that has owned Glitter's master rights since 1997, confirmed to USA TODAY that the singer would not be making money off the film, explaining that Glitter will not be paid royalties or any other fees from the catalog.

The song featured in the film has found its way into many sports arenas as a stadium anthem and occasionally into movies such as "The Replacements" and "Meet the Fockers."

Former British pop star Gary Glitter, whose real name is Paul Gadd, is shown in a booking photo from the British Metropolitan police on Feb. 6, 2015. (Photo: AFP/Getty Images)

Glitter, whose real name is Paul Gadd, was sentenced in 2015 to 16 years in jail after being convicted of sexually abusing three young girls. He was found guilty of one count of attempted rape, four counts of indecent assault and one count of sexual intercourse with a girl under the age of 13.

Glitter's song feature was the latest bit of controversy for a movie that, while scoring a record-setting October opening of $93.5 million, has also ruffled feathers for its nihilistic take on the iconic Batman villain, shocking violence and security concerns at movie theaters.
